Situation1: They occasionally give casual advice when asked about minor career choices.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Story: I was sweeping up the last of the day’s hair clippings when the door chimed and in stormed Mrs. Patel, her face flushed with frustration. She jabbed a finger at her new bob, her voice rising, “This is not what I asked for!” The other stylists glanced at me, expecting me to handle it—after all, I was the senior hairdresser, the one who always smoothed things over. I could feel the weight of their expectations: keep the client happy, fix the cut, don’t let her leave angry. But as I listened, I realized Mrs. Patel’s daughter, Priya, was with her, looking embarrassed and lost. Priya had confided in me before about her uncertainty with college applications, and now she looked at me, silently pleading for reassurance. I wanted to pull her aside, offer the gentle guidance she needed, but Mrs. Patel’s complaints grew louder, demanding my full attention as a professional. My mind raced, torn between my duty to calm the client and my instinct to mentor Priya in this vulnerable moment. The clock ticked toward closing, and I stood there, caught between two worlds, unsure which role to step into first.
